titleStmt.title: [The banquett of dainties: for all suche gestes that love moderatt dyate.]

notesStmt.note: Title page lacking; title and imprint supplied in manuscript.
Running title reads: The banquet of dainties.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: English poetry -- Early modern, 1500-1700 -- Early works to 1800.

div.head: Authoris in auxilium inuocatio.
div.l: YE ſacred nymphs whoſe ſteps do trace
Ye ſiſters fayre whoſe princely grace
Aſſiſt and ayde the ſlender minde,
By painefull toyle to him aſſign
Exile from breaſt all childiſh feare,
To breath and blaſt in thundring verſe,
Or iunckets fine, ſuch to rehearſe,
Condect with pearle, adornd with ſtone,
Guide trembling ioyntes, guid fanſie frée,
So ſhall I paſſe, this toyling clogge,
Soe ſhall I ſcape the lothſom logge,
Come néere, we yeld to thy requeſt,
I thanke ye dames that your beheſt,
I gréet you all farewell a whyle,

div.head: Demoſthenes the Mayſter of the Banquet, Soſia his Stewarde.
div.l: To this my phraſe this audit tend,
I haue decréed for to conuiue,
With daintie meates, but firſt yle ſhriue
I walking through the prate or gréene,
Theſe Lanterns bright did vew a quéene,
He deckt with flamed ſhyning beames,
And from hir eyes large ſiluer ſtreames,
The Quéene the regall King did call,
their robes as gréene as graſſe,
Theſe ſights delited much my minde,
With ſerious toyle the place to finde,
through which their féete did paſſe.
In dumps I tended to and fro,
Yet laſt I preſſed for to goe,
And Fanſie Fanſie lyke did lead,
And brought me ſtraight vnto a bed,
where I did ſéeme to reſt:
So deckt with pleaſaunt Odours ſwéete,
That ſure I did ſuppoſe it méete,
And waking, dames with Torches bright,
The one a fading Roſe did beare,
The other Fortune as you heare,
With yt in Traunce my ſprites were gaſt
Scarſe breathing breathles was my heart,
That ſure I doubted pinching dart,
Then of a ſodaine, beauties Roſe,
And Lady Fortune, with hir gloſe,
O formoſe puer, numū ne crede colori. Cicero. pares cum paribus facilime congregantur. Alias, Similes habent labra lactucas.For on the wale fayre written was,
Which adage as it came to paſſe,
Than likewiſe in an other place,
With nipping cuts for to deface,
Inſculped briefe, if that the blinde,
the blinde do ſéeme to lead,
The prouerbe true néedes muſt I finde,
moe fooles are brought to bed.
Thus winding not from midſt my thrale,
Into a princelie court or hall,
The roufe whereof was Iuorie bone,
The windowes deckt with pearle & ſtone,
In midſt wherof a Bath did ſpring,
So rather that than any thing,
I would haue taſt the ſame.
Thus ſtill deſire did preſſe to proue,
And eke my gréedie minde did mone,
I faynted like a feble hound,
But yet the liquors did rebound,
when lippes were at the brinke.
Who when the waters proch him fayre,
Thus gaſing ſometime here and there,
Chaſtitas, Sapientia, Scientia.in midſt of all my griefe,
Thrée Nymphes of ſodaine did appeare,

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.l: My Leach if this be manifeſt,
I wonder much how you were bleſt,
Spied you in middeſt of Chriſtal ſtreame,
I doubt your worſhip did but dreame,

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: If Titans Chariot chaſe the ſkie,
Then this as true none can denie,

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.l: Then by requeſt might boldneſſe craue,

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: And finall thus I doe replie,
Dame Sapience, firſt, thē chaſted Quéene,
And Lady Science to be ſéene,
Ech offered me a precious gift,
But Science one my head did lift,
This done ſuche muſicke did abounde,
in Traunce my corps did fall.
Then at the latter pinch and eb,
When ſiſters black had ſhredde my web,
The Muſes hearing this my mone,
That verdit giuen of euery one,
Then, who coulde lyke mée ſhoulde mée haue,
This they decréed, to kéepe from graue,
Theſe golden darlings markt mée well,
And poynted Science laſt to dwell
with mée, for terme of lyfe
Content was pleaſde, ſhe gaue hir troth,
That whyle the ayre did féede vs both,
Then leade we were in ſacred wiſe,
Where Veſta by hir wonted guyſe,
Thus were we married, know the caſe
and this take by the way,
My wedding Banquet in this place,
Therefore ſuch Cates as coſtly be,
And thus much more attend to mée,

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.l: Farre fet they ſay and dearely bought,
Nowe euery corner muſt be ſought,
I runne, I trace, I fiſke and jette,
I raunge from ſtréete, to ſtreete
To kill with Hauke, or catch with nete,
ſuch wild foule as I meete.
Trudge Soſia, trudge, feſtine with ſpéede,
But Lixa, ſée the hounds ye féede,
I knowe not I, what Cates to buy,

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: I pray thée zelouſly my friende,
For péerles dames I doe intend,
Of dainties theſe let me not fayle,
Blauncht Almondes, as in court is ſéene,
Stewde Proynes, conſerue of Cherries red,
With nectar dulce, ſince I am wedde,

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.l: What Iunckets call ye theſe I pray,
For vulgar ſort from day to day,
They ſerue as foode for to ſuſtaine,
So that the Nimphes from them refraine,
For ſacred powers of ſtarrie ſkie,
to hath them where they liſt.
And ſequent then for to conclude,
What whight their fauors to delude,
Stay, ſtop therfore, pauſe and abide,

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: Thy iudgement ſoundeth to the eare,
And therefore gréedy more to heare,

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.l: There witleſſe will is brought a ſléepe,
Sus Miueruam.And then the prouerbes proufe is found.
Therefore with bended knée to grounde,
For what I woulde, I can not ſay,
and what I can, I may not,
procéede with ſpéede and ſtay not.

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: Why licence francke is graunted frée,
Set dread a part, and ſhewe to mée,

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.l: Where ignorance doth lead the route,
And therefore as you pardon graunt,
He is vnwiſe that ſeemes to vaunt,
For wiſedomes loare to take in hande,

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: Then tratting néede conſtraines to way,
Harke, Soſia marke this preſent day,
Whereby I may complet my will,
And I ſhall to the Temple hie,

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.l: Thy ſeruaunts will is readie bente,

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: Adew, adew, my friende ſo true

sp.speaker: Soſia.
sp.l: Farewell, in this though I be blinde,
yet I may drawe my bowe,
In ſuch a ſorte to pleaſe thy minde,

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: Where ebs, and flowes of painfull griefe
Of late my ghoſt, now miſbeliefe
In thraldomes thore (I) rule the roſt,
A pillor or a propping poſt,
Yet thoughe my fanſie naught can vaile,
But when that wilfull cares aſſaile,
Therefore ſince nothing is ſo dure,
As Poems doe my breaſt aſſure,
I minde to take the payne.
And this I knowe he is vnméete,
that will not taſt the ſower,
To be a guſter of the ſwéete,

sp.speaker: Scientia. Chaſtitas & Sapientia.
sp.l: Deare ſpouſe, what ſenſleſſe rage doth bind,
thy wittes in ſuch a maze?
Or elſe what fogges of miſtie minde,
do cauſe thée thus to gaze?

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: To vewe thy gliſtering eyes of Golde,
no man ſo glad as I.
And then he will define the caſe,

sp.speaker: Scientia.
sp.l: Science is bounde to yéeld by right,
And therefore ſée, with all my might,
take time while time may bée,
Meridies.For Phoebus meane doth nigh hand call,

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: Prouiſion that, néedes muſt I wayle,
For all my ſenſes doe me fayle,
Where ſhall I find, a daintie diſh?
For dainties none of fleſhe nor fiſh,
in all the worlde I ſpie.

sp.speaker: Sapience.
sp.l: Great ſtore, and plenteous plentie is
Reioyce therefore we will not miſſe,

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: O bliſfull Nimph, O Lamp of truſt,
In whome I hope and euer muſt,
I thanke thée thrice and ten times thrice,
That wiſedome thyne, through thy deuiſe,

sp.speaker: Chaſtitie.
sp.l: Where Science knits a perfect knot,
And chaſted lyfe deuoyde of ſpot,
The ſincere path, the rule of lyfe
The comforte-true of man or wyfe,
But briefly ſhewe what grieuous ſore,
That tranſingly ſtill more and more,

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: Is to conuiue, attend and heare,
But more I ſéeke, the more as wyde,
the marke I can not hit.

sp.speaker: Sapience.
sp.l: Learne well & marke, print in thy minde,
Iuuenal. Rara auis in terris, nigroque ſimillima Cygno.By friendſhip true which rare I finde,
In friendſhip fraude is this ye knowe,
And Fraude gaue Caeſar ſuch a blowe,
For ratling ſpeach with great diſdaine,
That where as loue was wont to raigne,
With roaring rage the Cannons rent,
Betwixt them both they did conuent,
Here Pompei led his valiaunt hoſt,
There valiaunt Caeſar ſéemed to boſt,
Here Pompei gaue the onſet frée,
Here Iulius was conſtraynd to flée,
Reporting that a boy to chaſe,
When Pompey thought he had the beſt,
Then Caeſar as a ſauſie geſt,
he preſt with ſpeare and ſhielde,
Of hautie minde, of courage ſtoute,
By whome his ſouldiars had no doubt,
When worde came to Pompeius eare,
With liuely hope douoyd of feare,
he toke his charge in hande.
on him to liue or die.
The Trumpets ſounded out full ſhrill,
No worde was there but ſlay and kill,
from morne till glead of Sunne.
his knées to earth did bende,
Yet valiauntly he did not quaile,
Declaring that the grounde did quake,
The ſouldiars gréedie of their pray,
And fought ſo cruell that ſame day,
the ſtrokes did ſounde to Heauen
The vewers of this dreadfull fight
that in the ayle we ſée.
But fickle Fortune chaunged at laſt,
To him, whome once he did reſtore,
That nowe with ſcepter in his Thore,
This prince as ſoone as he did ſée
For friendſhip his did ſtraight decrée,
of him to make an end.
But firſt in courtious ſort and ſkill,
And for to cloake his ſpitefull will,
he met him in the ſtréete,
Then feaſting him with roſt meat frée,
he beat him with the Spit,
And ſent him forth moſt Iudaſly,
To ſhewe him pleaſure to his paine,
For on the water he was ſlayne,
And ſtraight preſented for a gift,
Thus fickle Fortune driue the drift,
that chaunge of choyſe did lead.
Which for his truſt meſſe full plaine,
And whome he counted leaſt his foe,
By wilfull hap it chaunced ſoe,
did kill him in the ende.

Ouidius. En ego, non paucis quondam munitus amicis: Dum ſlauit velis aura ſecunda meis: vt fera nymboſo tumueruut aequora vē to: In medijs lacera puppe relinquor aquis.And Ouid ſayth if riches flowe,
Soe long the winde with thée wil blowe,
But when the day is ouercaſt,
Then will falſe friends from thee flée faſt,
Therrfore a daintie diſh it is,
Which in a tempeſt will not miſſe,
to proue to the full kinde,
True, Lodvvicke ſléepes in tōbe of ſtone,
In ſtead of loue, there hatred growes,
where truth ſhoulde take a place,
The ſtrongeſt Oke is ſeldome ſure,
The friend which friendly did indure,
The brother pareth for to gloſe,
And friends are chaunged ofte to foes,
Thus therefore for bycauſe I know,
Thy Banquet thinne, I will beſtow
That ſéeke abroad and ſeldome finde,
To whom thou mayeſt declare thy minde,

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: Of dainties all I muſt conſent,
For friendſhips Bow is ſeldome bent,
I thanke thée Sapience from the heart,
if it lie in my lotte,
Thy gentleneſſe which heales my ſmart,

sp.speaker: Sapientia,
sp.l: And I doe muſe what diligence,
For dutie due, is fledde away,
And true obedience at this day,
But ſtill indeuour with their might,
Goe vewe abroad in euerie coaſt.
and ſéeme a childe to traine
In Godly lyfe, and all is loſt,
As Ploughmen rude they doe prepare,
Whoſe deuſliſh fanſie had the care,
And trayned hir euen as the ſhéepe,
Who falling in a ſlombring ſléepe,
For Nero ſlit hir ſecret wombe,
to ſée if he coulde ſpie,
The tender cell, or chatrie Tombe,
where he was wont to lye.
Such ſmall regarde had he vnto,
That beaſtly nature made him doe,
Euen lyke I ſay at preſent ſtint,
So that the childrens breaſt as flint,
For when the parents taking paine,
at laſt doe waxe full olde,
The children wiſh to haue them ſlayne,
that they might haue their Golde.
Now plaine deceit, hath choſe a ſeate,
Nowe loue is colde, now children threat,
How manie buddes of humaine ſéede,
That will about their fayres procéede,
Nay euery man is fully bent,
So that they care not with aſſent,
Where ſpring the braunches of the trée,
Where ſhall you finde a ſimile
to ſet by him his foote.
If any aunſwere in this caſe,
For well I knowe that Phoebus face,
For plyant was he at a becke,
To take a Faggot one his necke,
And when as Abraham did declare,
But paciently he toke the croſſe,
What children nowe woulde pleaſed bée,
Or who would yéelde ſo quietly,
They be not borne, nor lyue by breade,
That couet rather to be dead,
Then farther to the whole effect,
And tell mée if you doe reſpect,
He was obedient, in ſo much
The doctrine pure, of Scriptures ſuch,
They framde his ſteps to vertues trace,
they learnde him how to knit,
The perfect webbe, of heauenly grace,
they rulde him with a bit.
They made him to ſuppreſſe deſire,
his tongue they ſought to iame,
Bicauſe of little ſparked of fyre,
They kept with rod of wiſedoms ſchoole,
ſo well he knewe the lawe.
They did diſcharge their dueties right,
they let him not to ſtray,
But cauſde him with an humble ſpright,
His othes were nay, his ſwearing yée,
His dealing was from craft full frée,

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: Why? then by this you ſéeme to proue,

sp.speaker: Science
sp.l: Not ſo but fanſie did mée moue,
both faultes to let thée ſée.
For if the Colt might ſéeme to raunge,
The Bit and Brydle would be ſtraunge,
And therefore ſince that euerie man,
But that the childe, doe what he can,
Omni morbo paratur medicina,Yet if the wounde were nere ſo ſore,
a ſalue is to be founde,
Which though it feſter more and more,
at laſt will make it ſounde.
But where as ſuffrance ſéemes to raigne,
As proufe by this we haue in hande,
But if they once begin to growe,
Though they their wicked haūt do know,
That rype, ſoone rotten when they bée,
So that their folly as ye ſée,
And therefore, ſhould they put in vre,
So long as breath doth lyfe procure,
For duetie ſlips, a good cauſe why,
Thus what by Tutours fondneſſe blinde,
The humble braunches ſtarke I finde
Therefore this daintie for a diſh,
For which a man maye often wiſh,
As much to ſaye, obedience flame,
So that an humble chylde by name,
For fanſie leades their thoughtes aſtray,
The righteous children for to play,
That is as long as any note,
They laſhe and lauiſh all a flote
The path that Ioſeph walked in,
is not for them to walke,
For why, their vertues verie thinne,
A Iuſtice diet in common place,
Thus pilgrime like, their race they runne,
to no good point at all,
But as the Wax againſt the Sunne,
That ſeldome ſure or not at all,
A man may trauaile where he ſhall,
And ſerue this for a ſecond meſſe,
Bicauſe thou doſt pretend as geſſe,

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: What ioyes vnto my breaſt aſpire?
Hir ſpeach hath ſet my heart one fyre,
hir talke hath ridde my payne.
A daintie diſhe it is in déede,
Where as the childe doth render méede,
For children nowe are better fedde,
Yes, right is wrong, and wrong is right,
The light is darke and darkeneſſe light,
the eyes that ſée be blind.
Thus daintie twayne I haue, but yet
the thirde is to be ſought,
Which, if that I coulde ſéeme to get,
full ſoone it ſhoulde be bought.

sp.speaker: Chaſtitie.
sp.l: Neyther can Golde attaine the ſame,
Nor princely money beare the name,
For coyne herein doth naught preuaile,
The ſcaling of the walles t'aſſaile,
And therefore ſince as Authors olde,
Not otherwiſe by courſe I will
the thirde diſh for to ende.
I maſe and muſe, in what degrée,
For well I ſpie, and plainely ſée,
They loue a whyle, the prouerbe olde
Theyr loue ſo whot is quickly colde,
Whoſe bended knées full ofte did bowe,
Of whome dame vertues braunches ryfe,
And wrought all meanes for to inlarge,
a ſalue his yre to peaſe.
that luld the ſoule a ſléepe.
For when the elders did conſpire,
By filthy luſt of fleſhly fire.
which made them ſo to raue.
That proching me, hir hathing place,
With flattering ſtyle, and craftie face,
The beames of grace did ſo inſpire,
That crackling ſparkes of fonde deſire,
She rather chuſed for to dye,
Loe here the fruite of faithfull ſtate,
loe, here both truſt and hope,
Loe, here dame vertue with hir mate,
doth ſéeme to tende hir ſcope.
Doth preſent time the lyke declare,
Vnto their faith to haue a care,
Nay faith is fledde, nay faith is dead,
nay faith is layed full lowe,
For euery wight, with vrgent ſpight,
Nowe Venus doth hir banquets make,
Proceeds herein the paynes to take,
Then firſt approcheth to his hande,
And nigh to hir there ſéemes to ſtande,
So that as guider of this ray,
And Venus as a rector ſtay,
Then Cupid with his bended Bowe,
Vpon thoſe veſſels weake and lowe,
Thus wyfes doe raunge in wofull ſort,
In leauing of their Thalame ſport,
to hunt the For a farre.
I will not ſay that all their might
In leauing of the perfect light,
For I their Odours ſo doe ſmell,
Their filthy ſhape, with hir to dwell,
of wedlocke many breake the hand,
Shall we, ſay they, as truſtie ſtand
to one whyle lyfe doth laſt.
Not ſo, and why bicauſe that ſhame,
That ſhameleſſe lyke their chaſted name,
Or at the leaſt if Venus net,
They doe indeuour for to get,
That is the Pehens proude to play,
By which they hope an other day,
With chafing broyle, and chyding checks,
To clogge and yoke their marits neckes,
that they might haue their will.
For one word twaine, for two words thrée,
And all is for the maſterie
Thus as the olde Cocke oft doth crowe,
With notes full ſhrill his voice to ſhowe,
For damſels deck their hearts with pride,
That all their care one euerie ſide,
They make a gibe, and ieſting ſtocke,
Their wicked factes, they grine and mock,
For if their chaſted lyfe beare ſway,
Or one and twentie and a day,
For banquets then of Venus kinde,
Then Virgins Lamp is ſtrocken blinde,
Thus wyfes be maſters as ye ſée,
to ſtriue it is no boote.
Here as the reſt hath giuen to thée,
That ſéeke to finde a truſtie wyfe,
For many fragile be full ryfe,

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: A truſtie friend an humble childe,
I doe adiure by Marie milde,
Now when it pleaſe, therefore to heare,
Moſt fitteſt for this royall chéere,
Firſt gaze I muche where Iuſtice true,
doth plead the poore mans caſe.
And right is rendred, where as due
ſhoulde ſéeme to haue a place.
For money makes them treade a wrie,
and turnes the Cat in panne,
Then ſecondly much more I muſe,
And laſt of all where ſhall we ſpy,
I doubt them all, yet may they be,
when as the ſea doth flame,
fewe ſuch doe beare a name.
Thus nowe I iudge my ſelfe well ſped,
That you would take the paynes to lead
And I the Muſes euerie one,
But bound to you all thrée alone,

sp.speaker: Sapince.
sp.l: I Wiſedome, Science by the palme,
And ſacred chaſted lyfe ſo calme,
Make haſt therefore and ſtay not long,

sp.speaker: Exeunt.
sp.l: to dyne to take the payne.

sp.speaker: Demoſt.
sp.l: Doubt not, what as your zeldus will
O withering graſſe, O fragile ſhade,
Whoſe honor as the Hay doth fade,
Where naughts but vanitie doth dwell,
A lurcking denne, a hollow cell,
Leaſt ſodenly that you be ſhent,
From which repentaunce may you bring
To reſt with that eternall King,
Well, tyme doth wiſh me to prepare,
To guſt and taſt of dainties rare,
which you haue heard vs ſigne.
And in meane ſeaſon I commend
